title: Eva Simpson: We should put the accent on ditching slang
text:

I’m forever telling off my teenage son for the way he talks. I’m sure I’m not alone, but the endless “well likes”, “wots” and “nahs” drive me up the wall.

My worry is he will be judged by the way he speaks and that people will make ­ill-informed judgments as a result.

And this week scientists proved I was right to be concerned.

Researchers at Yale ­University have discovered interviewers made immediate assumptions about a ­candidate’s socioeconomic status based on just a handful of words.

People seen as coming from a higher class were deemed as being more ­competent than someone of a lower social class. As a result, they were more likely to be recommended for higher starting salaries and signing up bonuses. All this based on just seven words.

In recent years there’s been a trend for people, especially ones with regional accents, to take elocution lessons to change the way they sound. Many have said they felt less confident about their jobs because of their voices.

I’ve certainly known where they’re coming from. For a long time I was hung up about the way I sounded.

I remember doing TV interviews when I was a 3am columnist and not wanting to speak because I didn’t like my South London accent. When I spoke I adopted this strange fake posh voice which a reader described as “upper-class rude girl”.

That still stings, but I agreed I sounded awful. I never felt the need to take elocution lessons like Margaret Thatcher but I made a conscious decision to slow down and speak more clearly.

Now my son tells me I sound, horror of horrors, posh. I disagree.

The way we sound is a huge part of who are, and clearly no one should have to erase who they are to get ahead or to feel comfortable at work.

But at the same time when you think about the dialects we hear every day on the TV and radio, posh accents ­dominate, which reinforces the ­stereotype that people who sound like that are naturally better at, well, everything.

We need to hear a more diverse range of accents to help break down these barriers. And we need to encourage young people to leave the slang at home sometimes so their voices don’t hold them back.

And finally, we should remember, the people with the plummiest voices aren’t always the best people for the job.

Just look at Boris Johnson.
description: Yale University researchers have proved the way we talk can hold us back, but we shouldn't be ashamed of our accents – they're a big part of who we are
